20.text: Access can be gained from Wiluna along the Wiluna North Road to a point 2.5km past the

21.text: intersection of the Kalgoorlie Gas Pipeline. From here a well maintained farm track trends in

22.text: a  southerly  direction  to  Yerrida  Spring  and  thence  via  often  poorly  defined  tracks  to  the

23.text: western  part  of  E51/1059  and  on  to  both  E51/1061  and  E51/1112.  The  eastern  part  of

24.text: E51/1059 can be accessed from the gas pipeline service road. There are few tracks within

25.text: the tenements themselves and thick vegetation and areas of rocky outcrop constrain the use

text:
Access can be gained from Wiluna along the Wiluna North Road to a point 2.5km past the 
 intersection of the Kalgoorlie Gas Pipeline. From here a well maintained farm track trends in 
 a  southerly  direction  to  Yerrida  Spring  and  thence  via  often  poorly  defined  tracks  to  the 
 western  part  of  E51/1059  and  on  to  both  E51/1061  and  E51/1112.  The  eastern  part  of 
 E51/1059 can be accessed from the gas pipeline service road. There are few tracks within 
 the tenements themselves and thick vegetation and areas of rocky outcrop constrain the use 
 of 4WD motor vehicles.

•  The  Maraloou  Formation,  consisting  of  thin  bedded  siltstone  and  black  shales 
 with carbonaceous and sulphidic bands outcrops in the central and western parts 
 Copper  mineralisation  in  the  form  of  malachite,  cuprite  and  chrysocolla  occurs  at  the 
 Thaduna and Ricci mines located 70km northwest of the project.  
 Mineral exploration over the project area has been regional in scale with little detailed work 
 The  Peak  Hill  1:250,000  scale  map  sheet  was  included  in  the  GSWA’s  regional  regolith 
 geochemical  mapping  program. Samples  were  collected at a nominal  density of 1  sample 
 per  16  square  km  to  give  a  total  of  1,014  samples.  Based  on  orientation  studies  the  –
 2mm/+0.45mm  fraction  was  selected  for  analysis.  Samples  were  analyzed  for  48 
 components.  A  regional  regolith  map  was  produced  as  part  of  the  survey.  Regional 
 Analytical data from the GSWA regional regolith survey show that E51/1059 covers a large 
 multi-element  geochemical  anomaly  which  suggests  the  presence  of  PGE-Cu-Ni  sulphide 
 mineralization. Pt values are especially high and are accompanied by anomalous Cu, Ni, Pd, 
 intrusion  as  well  as  possible  Au 
 mineralization  hosted  by  a  differentiated  mafic 
 Au, Co, Zn, Sb and other elements. Platinum values include some of the highest values from 
 the  Peak  Hill  survey  including  the  second  highest  value  of  47ppb.  Copper  values  in  and 
 around the licence include the second highest value of the 1014 samples collected from the 
 Peak Hill sheet and 5 values are in the top 0.1% of the population. Ni values include four 
 values in the top 10% of the dataset.  Gold values within the licence range up to 10ppb 
 E51/1061 covers the peak of a large regional regolith gold anomaly. Sample sites within the 
 licence returned Au values of up to 17ppb and include values of 10ppb and 11ppb Au. The 
 anomaly,  defined  by  a  contour  value  of  4ppb  Au,  extends  at  least  25km  to  the  north-
 northeast, extending through to E51/1059. The peak value of 17ppb Au is the tenth highest 
 Au  value  of  the  2035  samples  from  the  Peak  Hill  and  Glengarry  sheets.  Almost  all  the 
 samples  that  returned higher  Au  values  were  taken  in the  immediate  vicinity  of  known  Au 
 deposits.  The  gold  anomaly  is  accompanied  by  elevated  values  of  Cu  and,  to  a  lesser

18.text: CRA Exploration Pty Ltd (CRA) held E51/367, which covered the current E51/5112, which

19.text: was part of a CRA’s  Ruby Bore/Good Pool project which consisted of at least 17 exploration

20.text: licences.  The  area  was  explored  for  diamonds,  gold  and  base  metals  between  1987  and

21.text: 1995. Work done included aerial photography, mapping, stream and soil sampling, rock chip

22.text: sampling, reinterpretation of earlier aeromagnetics, follow up helimag and ground magnetic

23.text: surveys and limited drilling.  The geochemistry did not include analyses for Pt or Pd.

24.text: Exco Resources NL held E51/893 as part of its Cunyu Project. The licence covered portions

25.text: of what are now E51/1059, E51/1061 and the area between the licences. The exploration

26.text: target was magmatic Ni-Cu-PGE mineralization. Exco carried out reconnaissance fieldwork

27.text: which included collecting rock chip and stream sediment samples. Exco’s rock chip sampling

28.text: returned values of up to 36ppb Au, 57ppb Pt and 6ppb Pd, 574ppm Ni, 375ppm Cu, 540ppm

31.text: sample  returned  an  extremely  anomalous  Au  value  of  454ppb  [Wetherley,  2002:  Wamex

33.text: Exco  joint  ventured  the project  with  Rio  Tinto  Exploration  who  carried out  a  wide  spaced,

34.text: 500m line spacing Tempest aerial EM and magnetic survey over the entire Cunyu Project

35.text: area. Three EM targets were identified within E51/893; Curra, Parke West and Oval. Curra,

36.text: within current E51/1059, was tested by 22 RAB / aircore holes comprising a total of 840m of

37.text: drilling. One 232m reverse circulation/diamond tail hole was drilled at the Oval Prospect in

38.text: what is now E51/1061. It was concluded that in both areas the EM anomalies were due to

39.text: sulphidic sediments. No further work was done and there was no follow up of anomalous Au

40.text: values returned by GSWA regolith samples or Exco samples.

and Pt. The Au and Pt values reported in the GSWA survey were not reproduced and Perilya 
 relinquished the ground [Kwiecien ,1997.  
 CRA Exploration Pty Ltd (CRA) held E51/367, which covered the current E51/5112, which 
 was part of a CRA’s  Ruby Bore/Good Pool project which consisted of at least 17 exploration 
 licences.  The  area  was  explored  for  diamonds,  gold  and  base  metals  between  1987  and 
 1995. Work done included aerial photography, mapping, stream and soil sampling, rock chip 
 sampling, reinterpretation of earlier aeromagnetics, follow up helimag and ground magnetic 
 surveys and limited drilling.  The geochemistry did not include analyses for Pt or Pd. 
 Exco Resources NL held E51/893 as part of its Cunyu Project. The licence covered portions 
 of what are now E51/1059, E51/1061 and the area between the licences. The exploration 
 target was magmatic Ni-Cu-PGE mineralization. Exco carried out reconnaissance fieldwork 
 which included collecting rock chip and stream sediment samples. Exco’s rock chip sampling 
 returned values of up to 36ppb Au, 57ppb Pt and 6ppb Pd, 574ppm Ni, 375ppm Cu, 540ppm 
 Cr,  243ppm  Co  and  3.29%Pb      Several  of  the  stream  sediment  samples  from  the  limited 
 sampling  program  returned  Au  values  in  the  range  of  6  to  9ppb.    One  stream  sediment 
 sample  returned  an  extremely  anomalous  Au  value  of  454ppb  [Wetherley,  2002:  Wamex 
 Exco  joint  ventured  the project  with  Rio  Tinto  Exploration  who  carried out  a  wide  spaced, 
 500m line spacing Tempest aerial EM and magnetic survey over the entire Cunyu Project 
 area. Three EM targets were identified within E51/893; Curra, Parke West and Oval. Curra, 
 within current E51/1059, was tested by 22 RAB / aircore holes comprising a total of 840m of 
 drilling. One 232m reverse circulation/diamond tail hole was drilled at the Oval Prospect in 
 what is now E51/1061. It was concluded that in both areas the EM anomalies were due to 
 sulphidic sediments. No further work was done and there was no follow up of anomalous Au 
 values returned by GSWA regolith samples or Exco samples. 
 6.  CURRENT EXPLORATION 
 A total of primary 195 stream sediment samples and 16 field duplicates were collected from 
 the three tenements in the project area. Landsat imagery and stream patterns derived from 
 digital stream data off the Peak Hill 1:250, 000 scale topographic map were used to plan a 
 sample net to provide optimum coverage of basin drainage areas. The weathering resistant 
 Killara basalt forms low rounded hills which tend to define the major watershed boundaries. 
 Streams in general tend to be well defined in the upstream portions but become increasingly 
 braided downstream. 
 - 6 -
